questions.text: A 10 year old girl presented with short stature, dorsal edema of hands & feet, webbed neck and low posterior hairline. USG abdomen shows a small uterus and streak gonads bilaterally. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Short stature and lymphedema (swelling) of the hands and feet are common in Turner Syndrome.

Webbed neck and low posterior hairline are classic physical findings.

Small uterus and streak gonads on ultrasound are consistent with Turner Syndrome, as affected individuals often have underdeveloped sexual characteristics due to gonadal dysgenesis.

Other options:

Edward Syndrome (Trisomy 18): Low birth weight, prominent occiput, clenched hands, rocker-bottom feet, heart defects, severe intellectual disability.

Down Syndrome (Trisomy 21): Flat face, upslanting eyes, single palmar crease, hypotonia, intellectual disability, heart defects.

Klinefelter Syndrome (47,XXY): Tall males with gynecomastia, small testes, infertility, learning difficulties, and low testosterone.

Key takeaways:-Turner syndrome

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: Cottage loaf heart- Truncus Arteriosus

questions.text: A cyanotic child is having the CXR findings as shown in the image. What is correct?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray in the image shows a characteristic "snowman appearance," which is associated with Supracardiac Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC).

Other options:-

Option A - Coeur en sabot (boot-shaped heart) - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

Option B - Egg-shaped heat - Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA)

Option D - Cottage loaf heart - Truncus Arteriosus

Key takeaway:-Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC).

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: An 8 year old boy presents with generalize edema, pallor and hyperlipidemia, with serum cholesterol of 238 mg/dl. His urine microscopy shows 3+ urinary protein and oval fat bodies were also present. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario generalized edema, pallor, hyperlipidemia, high proteinuria (3+), oval fat bodies in urine, which indicate lipiduria & Elevated cholesterol.most probably diagnosis will be nephrotic syndrome.

Other options:

Option A - Acute Nephritic Syndrome: More commonly has hematuria and hypertension, not heavy proteinuria or lipiduria.

Option C - Goodpasture Syndrome: Features hemoptysis and hematuria, not significant proteinuria or hyperlipidemia.

Option D - Urinary Tract Infection: Presents with urinary symptoms, not edema, heavy proteinuria, or lipiduria.

Key takeaway:-nephrotic syndrome

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: An Anganwadi worker performs anthropometry of a 4 year old child and she finds that the child has height for age below -2 SD. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
Height for age below -2 standard deviations (SD) indicates stunting, which is a sign of chronic malnutrition. It reflects long-term nutritional deficiency or repeated infections affecting growth over time.

Other options:

Option A - Acute Malnutrition: Typically indicated by weight-for-height below -2 SD or wasting, not height-for-age.

Option C - Wasting: Reflects low weight for height, indicating acute malnutrition.

Option D - Recent infection: May cause temporary weight loss but does not directly affect height-for-age.

Key takeaways:-

Malnutrition in children aged 6 to 59 months

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Which of the following vessels carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta in fetal circulation?
questions.solution:
In fetal circulation, the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus back to the placenta. The umbilical vein, in contrast, carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.

Other options:-

Option B - Umbilical Vein: The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus, providing it with oxygen and nutrients.

Option C - Pulmonary Vein: In the postnatal circulation, the pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart, but in fetal circulation, the lungs are not used for oxygenation, so this vessel is not involved.

Option D - Inferior Vena Cava: The inferior vena cava carries mixed blood (oxygenated from the placenta and deoxygenated from fetal systemic circulation) back to the fetal heart.

Key takeaway:


Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: Blood Culture + CSF Culture, with CSF taken through LP
Blood Culture + CSF Culture, with CSF taken through Shunt

questions.text: A child with hydrocephalus underwent placement of a V-P shunt. Post operatively, the child developed fever and irritability. He was given acetaminophen in age-appropriate dosage. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
In given case scenario Fever and irritability postoperatively in a child with a V-P shunt suggest a possible shunt infection. Blood and CSF cultures are essential, and obtaining CSF through the shunt is preferred to directly assess infection in the shunt system.

Other options:

Option A - Urgent Neuroimaging - not the immediate next step unless there are signs of shunt malfunction.

Option B - Radionuclide Scan - not typically used for infection assessment.

Option C - CSF through LP - less preferred, may not accurately reflect shunt infection.

Key takeaway:-

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: MRI Brain for temporal lobe sclerosis

questions.text: A child presented with decline in scholastic performance and myoclonic jerks. There is a history of fever with rash at 1 year of age. EEG shows a periodic pattern with polyspikes, slow waves and burst suppression. Which investigation will give you the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Findings:

Decline in scholastic performance

Myoclonic jerks

EEG: Polyspikes, slow waves, burst suppression

Diagnosis:

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE), caused by persistent measles infection

Diagnostic Test:

IgG antibodies in CSF (confirming measles-specific antibodies)

Other options:-

Option A - EMG: This would assess muscle electrical activity and is more relevant for neuromuscular disorders, not SSPE.

Option B - MRI Brain for temporal lobe sclerosis: While useful for diagnosing conditions like epilepsy or hippocampal sclerosis, it wouldn't specifically diagnose SSPE.

Option D - Anti-GQ1b antibodies in CSF: These are typically associated with Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) and not relevant to SSPE.

Key takeaway:-

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A child presented with anemia, mental retardation, bone pains and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy showed "crumpled tissue paper" appearance. What is the enzyme deficiency producing this condition?
questions.solution:
clinical presentation of anemia, mental retardation, bone pains, hepatosplenomegaly, and a

"crumpled tissue paper"appearance on bone marrow biopsy slide finding in given image , is

indicative of Gaucher disease. This condition is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme

Glucocerebrosidase

Other options :

Option A - Hexosaminidase-A: Deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease (cherry-red spot, neurodegeneration)

Option B - Iduronate-2-sulfatase: Deficiency leads to Hunter syndrome (coarse features, joint stiffness)

Option C - Glucose-6-Phosphatase: Deficiency causes Von Gierke disease (hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A 10 year old boy who is previously unimmunized, presented to you at OPD. Which one of the following vaccines will you administer?
questions.solution:
A 10-year-old child who is previously unimmunized,for this age group under NIS there is option 2 option JE vaccine(maximum cut off age 15yrs) & Td (there is no cut off age).

Other options:-

Option A - BCG is typically given at birth or i 1yr age.

Option B - Rabies vaccine is only administered after potential exposure or in high-risk situations.

Option C - Typhoid vaccine is not routinely administered in this scenario unless there is an increased risk of typhoid fever.

Key takeaways:-

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: Protein losing enteropathy is the diagnosis
Rectal prolapse occurs on treatment
Distal intestinal obstruction can occur

questions.text: A 9 year old boy presented with recurrent chest infections with steatorrhea and elevated stool fat content. What is the correct statement?
questions.solution:
Recurrent chest infections and steatorrhea (fatty stools) suggest Cystic Fibrosis (CF).

Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome (DIOS) is a known complication in Cystic Fibrosis due to thickened mucus obstructing the intestines.DIOS presents with Abdominal pain, bloating, and sometimes vomiting.

Other options:-

Option A - Hypernatremia: Incorrect. Hyponatremia is common in cystic fibrosis due to excessive salt loss in sweat.

Option. B - Protein losing enteropathy is not a feature of Cystic fibrosis. in Cystic fibrosis mainly fat malabsorption occurs.

Option C -Rectal prolapse occurs on treatment: Incorrect. Rectal prolapse can occur in untrained patients due to chronic cough and bulky stools,but on treatment it doesn't happen.

Key takeaway:-Cystic Fibrosis

Complications of Cystic Fibrosis

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: An infant presented with multiple episodes of projectile non-bilious vomiting post-feeds and epigastric mass with hard pellet stools. What complication to expect?
questions.solution:
In a given case scenario multiple episode of projectile,non bilious vomiting ,Epigastric mass suggestive of CHPS(Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis).

persistent vomiting causes a loss of hydrogen (H+) and chloride (Cl-) ions, leading to hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

Due to adequate fluid loss in vomiting, activated RAAS result in Hypokalemia.

Key takeaway:-CHPS

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: Closure of fossa ovalis prematurely
Closure of ductus arteriosus prematurely
Closure of patent foramen ovale prematurely
Higher risk of developing Patent Ductus Arteriosus

questions.text: A pregnant female at 34 weeks gestation was inadvertently given oral indomethacin for body pains. What can be the consequences?
questions.solution:
Indomethacin, an NSAID, can inhibit prostaglandin synthesis, which is essential to keep the ductus arteriosus open in the fetus.

Administering indomethacin in the third trimester risks premature closure of the ductus arteriosus.

Key takeaway:-Ductus arteriosus

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A 6 year old child presents with hypertension. On examination, his lower limb pulses are feeble and delayed compared to the upper limb pulses. CXR showed inferior notching of the ribs. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Findings

Hypertension: Due to increased resistance in the narrowed aorta.

Feeble and delayed lower limb pulses: Reduced blood flow to the lower body from the aortic narrowing.

Inferior rib notching on CXR: Caused by collateral circulation through the intercostal arteries, leading to rib erosion.

On the basis of given case scenario most likely diagnosis is Coarctation of aorta

Other options:-

Option A - Atrial Septal Defect: Causes a murmur, not hypertension or differential pulses.

Option C - Bicuspid Aortic Valve: Linked to aortic stenosis or regurgitation, not the specific findings here.

Option D - Patent Ductus Arteriosus: Typically causes a continuous murmur, not pulse differences or rib notching.

Key Takeaway:- Coarctation of aorta

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A 6 year old female child presents with bony deformities and rickets-like features. She has received multiple courses of Vitamin D without any benefits. Her investigations revealed Serum Calcium of 9.5 mg/dl, Serum Phosphate of 1.6 mg/dl, Serum Alkaline Phosphatase of 819 IU/L and a normal blood pH, normal Serum PTH levels. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Low Phosphate and Normal Calcium: Suggest phosphate-related bone disorder.

Normal PTH and Normal pH: Rule out Vitamin D deficiency or renal issues.

Failure to Respond to Vitamin D: Points to phosphate metabolism problem.

High Alkaline Phosphatase: Indicates rickets.

On the basis of given case scenario most likely diagnosis is X-linked Hypophosphatemic Rickets

Other options:

Option A - Renal Osteodystrophy: Unlikely, as the child has normal kidney function and no signs of uremia.

Option B - VDDR Type 1: Unlikely, as it causes low calcium and elevated PTH, which are not present here.

Option C - VDDR Type 2: Unlikely, as it causes elevated PTH and low calcium, which are absent in this child.

Key Takeaway:-

Refractory Rickets(if there is no clinical,biochemical or radiological improvement after 90days of VitD & Calcium supplementation

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A child with HIV develops Pneumonia. What is the most likely pathogen in this child?
questions.solution:
Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PCP) is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-infected individuals, especially with low CD4 counts. It presents with pneumonia symptoms like cough, difficulty breathing, and fever, and is a key indicator of AIDS.

Other options:

Option A - Streptococcus pyogenes typically causes throat infections but can also cause pneumonia, though it's less common in HIV patients compared to PCP.

Option B -Atypical mycobacteria can cause respiratory infections, but this is rarer compared to Pneumocystis jiroveci in the context of HIV.

Option D - Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes diphtheria, which affects the upper respiratory tract rather than causing pneumonia.

Key Takeaway:-Opportunistic infection in HIV positive individuals

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A 3 month old child has recurrent candidiasis and chest infections. She is currently undergoing immune work-up and is found to have low CD4 count. Which vaccine should always be avoided in this child?
questions.solution:
Low CD4 count suggesting possible immunodeficiency.

Live vaccines are generally avoided due to the risk of causing disease in immunocompromised children.

Measles is a live attenuated vaccine.

Other options:-

Option A and B - DPT and IPV are inactivated vaccines, which are safe in immunocompromised children.

Option D - Tetanus toxoid (TT) is also a killed vaccine and can be safely given in immunocompromised children.

Key Takeaway:-

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: A child with tachypnea in emergency developed carpopedal spasms. Likely reason?
questions.solution:
Key Takeaway:-

Signs for elicit latent tetany

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: An 8 year old male child presents with multiple petechiae on both lower limbs along with joint pains and abdominal pain. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Findings:

Multiple petechiae on lower limbs

Joint pain

Abdominal pain

Likely Diagnosis:

Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP), a small-vessel vasculitis commonly affecting children, characterized by purpura (often on lower limbs), joint pain, and abdominal pain.

Other options:-

Option B - Kawasaki Disease (KD): Typically presents with fever, conjunctivitis, oral changes, rash, and swollen lymph nodes; petechiae are uncommon.

Option C - Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN): Affects medium-sized vessels, causing systemic symptoms and abdominal pain, but usually lacks petechiae or purpura.

Option D -Cryoglobulinemia: May cause purpura but is rare in children and often includes renal involvement and peripheral neuropathy

Key Takeaway:-HSP

Ref:-Nelson textbook of paediatric
